reasoning: The critique targets an important pivot in the essay’s Section 2 argument for “eutopian fragility”: that single non-obvious moral mistakes can wipe out a large fraction of attainable value and thereby make mostly-great futures rare. If that claim were substantially undermined, the intuitive/motivating route to “no easy eutopia” is weakened, though the essay also has an independent, more technical route via bounded/unbounded value functions and resource-scaling that could still support fussiness—so centrality is moderate (~0.6), not total. The critique’s main point is that the essay often establishes moral disagreement and the possibility of ‘catastrophe on some views’ without justifying that typical single flaws push value below the 0.5 threshold across a wide swath of reasonable views; it also flags a slide from “some plausible views” to “no safe option on most reasonable views.” These are legitimate argumentative gaps and would force the authors to do more quantitative/cross-theory work, but they do not fully refute the position because (i) multiple-flaw accumulation and (ii) Section 3’s fussiness arguments can still generate narrow targets even if any one flaw is only moderately costly. The critique is mostly correct, with some speculative magnitude claims (e.g., 5–20%) and a somewhat quick inference that ‘moderate typical loss’ would make the target non-narrow. It is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Historical moral errors show prevalence, not that single flaws cause massive value loss
